text: Welcome to Volume one of the Stanford Video Journal. My name is Don Knuth.
I'm a professor of computer science here at Stanford. And it's been my honor to to have a chance to be actually in in volume one of what we
think is an exciting new experiment to which which looks already to be successful,
as far as I can see. It's about a course that I that I talked last quarter.
Every two years I teach this course across computer science, two or four, which is officially called a problem seminar.
And and the I guess I'll say a few more words about that in a minute.
But before I go into the details of the course, let me say something about Stanford Video Journal.
This the general idea is that we would like to use the medium of television to distribute
information and that is is unsuitable or are probably can't even be made available in print.
We we've gotten used to to get better and better ways of communicating over the years.
And and and now video seems to be a excellent way to improve.
Still, moreover, what we've been able to do in the past with with all other kinds of communication.
So there are the plans are that Stanford Video Journal is going to have three different sorts of things.
First, there would be if there's some fast breaking developments in a new field.
This can be this can be captured on video and sent out very, very quickly before without having to try to make a formal publication of it.
Second kind of thing is that there are many happenings, the one time only things that that occur.
And on the Stanford campus and of course, in other places that many of them are historically important.
And we really want to have a way to to make this available to more people and can really be present at that at that time.
And so this this gives us a unique way to preserve it. And thirdly, there are many processes that that are much more easily communicated through video than through traditional printed media.
And this is what we want to see if we can't capitalize on.
In fact, that's the that's what this first Bime is all about is is to take the course that that I led last quarter and and let other people experience it.
Then the students who happen to be who happen to be here at the time. Now, why would you care about such a course?
There's millions of courses all over the world. Well, I think discourse is is especially nice, not only because it's fun for me to teach it, but because of the.
But because it's it it focuses on the on something that most courses don't cover.
I think it's probably the most important gap in the educational in the educational system, namely, how is recorded.
How does research get done. What. What's involved in in creating new ideas?
So it's, of course, very important to communicate the results of research and to tell people how what what the
facts are and and have them memorize those important concepts that others have discovered.
But somehow in our American educational system, we have we have had less emphasis on creativity.
And after maybe up until maybe the fifth or sixth grade after that.
People think there's no time anymore to allow the students to be creative, but they have to start cramming in the facts that have been learned.
And as a result, students get get too good at only the absorbing part of it.
And they they tend to miss the what I think is even more exciting,
the the idea of how did people come up with the ideas and new ideas and how are we going to come up with next year's idea.
And so that's what this course is about. And I'm trying to show how how research takes place by actually experiencing it, by actually play.
By play. I've seen research in action and.
Of course, one of the things that goes on is that people make mistakes when they're working.
So as you watch this, as you watch this class,
you'll be able to see all kinds of places where I stumbled and and where the where the students working with me.

It was going to work. And the although the course is called problem seminar, it's really the the old the old name was Problem and Programing Seminar.
And the older name was programing seminar. It's a combination of problems and programing which are really not that much not that different.
The history of this course, I think it goes back to George Poya in the math department to George would run a course,
something like this for the mathematicians in the 50s and the 60s and then Joe's foresight.
And then he found a computer science thought that was such a great idea. He started teaching a course. He has two or four in the 60s. And then the course was taken over by Bob Floyd.
And then then I started alternating with Bob Chargin and now our inspire. So we've been teaching it. So the course goes back for many years.
At one time, it was the only required course in the country for a computer science graduate student.
So we're saying that if you read the code like it says, you should take these two or four and any other courses that you want.
We decided that that was not a good idea because we didn't want any clothes to be required.
If there was there was one person out of 20 taking a course against his will.
There wasn't any good for the spirit of the class. And so although most people take it, take it gladly.
The main thing is to enjoy what we're doing and not to not to be forced in anything.
So it's so there's no longer any required courses in our department. But at one time, it was at least required because the faculty seemed to think it was a prudent course.

every two years because it takes me about two years to think of five good enough problems.
The problems are, in general, things that haven't been done before.
So we're breaking new ground. That's the best way to do research is to is to actually do something new there.
And so in I think in most of these cases, we're going to be doing things that that are we're going to be taking care of things that are original.
